Bangladeshâ€™s human development achievements
Bangladesh performed better than expected since independence in 1971 ï‚§ It will partially achieve MDGs for poverty reduction and primary enrolment, and is on track for gender parity in education, child mortality, maternal health, HIV/AIDs and tuberculosis ï‚§ This resulted from attention to health outcomes, primary education, family planning, and gender equality (especially in education and workforce participation), supported by female grass-roots workers and organizers mobilized by the GoB and world-leading NGOs
Social indicators for Bangladesh, India and sub-Saharan Africa Indicator Bangladesh India Sub-Saharan Africa 1971* 2011 1971* 2011 2011 GDP per capita (PPP$) n/a 1,883** n/a 3,876** 2,367 Life expectancy at birth 39 69 50 66 55 Infant mortality rate 150 37 114 44 69 Under-5 mortality rate 225 46 166 65 109 Total fertility rate 6.9 2.2 5.4 2.5 4.9 Access to improved sanitation (%) n/a 55 n/a 35 30 Mean years of schooling, age 25+ 2 4.8 2 4.4 n/a Literacy rate, age 15-24 (%) Female 27 80 40 [74] 65 Male 44 77 66 [88] 76 Prevalence of undernourishment 35 17 27 18 25 (%) Child immunization rates (%) DPT 1 96 6 72 71 Measles 1 96 1 74 74 Notes: *or earliest available **2012; [..] estimate; Source: World Development Indicators  Development Track Record (4)
Bangladesh has done well, but other countries did even better
GDP per capita, PPP (current GNI per capita, PPP (current international $) international $) 1980 2012 CAGR 1980 2012 CAGR India 425 3870 7.1 430 3820 7.1 Sri Lanka 750 6146 6.8 760 6030 6.7 Indonesia 662 4876 6.4 640 4730 6.5 South Korea 2398 30011 8.2 2360 30180 8.3 Thailand 1075 9660 7.1 1070 9280 7.0 Philippines 1356 4339 3.7 1340 4380 3.8 China 253 9083 11.8 250 9040 11.9 Bangladesh 319 1851 5.6 310 2030 6.0 Source: WDI *CAGR: Compound Annual Growth Rate  Growth Constraints (1)
Infrastructure deficiencies pose serious impediments to growth
Ranking of Bangladesh in 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015 Global Competitiveness Indicators Rank/133 Rank/139 Rank/142 Rank/144 Rank/148 Rank/148 Rank/140

Source: The Global Competitiveness Report (2008-2015)
â€¢ Acceleration of the growth rate will require a substantial increase in the rate of investment from the present level of 28.7 percent of GDP (FY14) â€¢ Much of the higher investment will need to be deployed to reduce the infrastructure constraint (primarily in the power and transport sectors)  Growth Constraints (2)
Private sector continues to face binding constraints to job creation
Top-Most Concerns of Businesses in Bangladesh
â€¢ Bangladesh has potential to generate more productive job opportunities at home
â€¢ The availability and reliability of power supply is a key concern for businesses
â€¢ Only 31 percent of adults in Bangladesh have access to a bank account  Growth Constraints (3)
Key governance and public sector challenges
â€¢ Divisive and confrontational politics can create policy uncertainty and impede efforts to address critical problems requiring long-term engagement â€¢ Bureaucratic red-tape and widespread rent-seeking impede growth and investment â€¢ Many Bangladeshi institutions, established when the country was at much lower levels of income, are not adequate for a country that joined middle-income status o Many utilities do not operate on a commercial basis o There is no integrated financial management information system o State-owned commercial banks have recently been plagued with several financial scams
Bangladeshâ€™s fluctuating CPIA rating 4.3
4.1 CPIA SUB-COMPONENT RATING
3.9 Economic Management 3.7 Social Inclusion/Equity 3.5 Overall CPIA
3.3 Structural Policies 3.1
2.9 Public Sector Management and Institutions 2.7 2005 2006 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014  Systematic Country Diagnostic (1)
SCD Findings: More and Better Jobs Needed for Faster Progress on Twin Goals
ï‚§ Jobs top the development agenda in Bangladesh o Labor force growing by 3.1 percent per year o Output per worker nearly four times higher in industry, services vs. agriculture o 45% of workforce in agriculture (which contributes 20% of GDP) o 34% in services (contributes 50% of GDP) o 20% in industry (contributes 30% of GDP) o 21m people projected to enter work force 2015-2025
ï‚§ Effective public policy needed to help create jobs with higher value addition in the economy by: o Removing binding constraints to growth o Promoting conditions for strong private sector-led growth job creation
ï‚§ SCD identifies priority areas of action for policymakers: o Transformational Priorities: key public policy areas where concerted action over next 3-5 years could have marked impact on progress toward twin goals o Foundational Priorities: pre-requisites for faster job creation and growth--areas where Bangladesh has done generally well and must sustain that progress  Systematic Country Diagnostic (2)
SCD : Transformational Priorities for Bangladesh INLAND CONNECTIVITY & REGIONAL & GLOBAL ENERGY LOGISTICS INTEGRATION â€¢ Increase supply of electricity â€¢ Upgrade and integrate key â€¢ Tap considerable potential to and natural gas. transport corridors (esp. capture higher share of manufacturing jobs moving out of â€¢ Diversify sources of power Dhaka-Chittagong highway). higher-income countries by reviving supply. â€¢ Improve management of stalled trade reform agenda. â€¢ Retire polluting and expensive Chittagong port. â€¢ Move up to higher value added emergency diesel generators. â€¢ Revive inland water transport. manufacturing; â€¢ Eliminate energy subsidies â€¢ Improve maintenance of â€¢ Make migration more remunerative, affordable, inclusive, (and resulting fiscal burden). existing assets. and safe. â€¢ Eliminate distorted market signals.
ADAPTIVE DELTA URBANIZATION MANAGEMENT â€¢ Improve urban competiveness â€¢ Promote agricultural productivity and livability, especially for the and diversification. poor (e.g. connectivity, â€¢ Enhance long-term planning for efficient land use, public better land and water use and natural resource management. services). â€¢ Revitalize and strengthen key â€¢ Reduce environmental infrastructure to protect the externalities (air & water population, reduce vulnerability, pollution). and secure growth  Systematic Country Diagnostic (3)
SCD : Foundational Priorities for Bangladesh
MACROECONOMIC STABILITY & RELATED CROSS- INSTITUTIONAL & BUSINESS HUMAN DEVELOPMENT CUTTING CHALLENGES ENVIRONMENT
â€¢ Achieve higher revenue â€¢ Reduce malnutrition â€¢ Stronger institutions needed mobilization through tax â€¢ Improve quality of public to: policy & tax administration service delivery (including â€¢ Manage larger and more reforms. workforce skills). complex economy, â€¢ Better implementation of â€¢ Increase public funding for â€¢ Meet aspirations of more Annual Development health and moving towards diverse and heterogeneous Program. universal health coverage. population â€¢ Improve health of financial â€¢ Extend coverage of social â€¢ Ensure business environment sector and enhance financial protection to urban poor. is conducive to higher intermediation. investment and growth.  Country Partnership Framework (1)
Bangladesh Country Partnership Framework for FY16-FY20
Systematic Country Performance Completion Country Partnership & Learning & Learning Diagnostic Framework Review Review
â€¢ Overarching goal is to create more and better jobs for Bangladesh. â€¢ Unified across the World Bank Group. All CPFs are Joint. â€¢ Bangladesh first country in South Asia to develop CPF â€¢ For greater impact on achieving twin goals, CPF proposes selective engagement based on: ïƒ¼Consistency with Governmentâ€™s 7th Five Year Plan to ensure strong country ownership; ïƒ¼Alignment with policy priorities identified in the SCD; and ïƒ¼WBG comparative advantage, taking into account knowledge and financing support provided by other development partners.  Country Partnership Framework (2)
Proposed Areas of Focus and Results Framework
Growth and Climate & Competitiveness Social Inclusion Environment Management â€¢ Increased power generation capacity & â€¢ Improved access and electricity supply quality of education â€¢ Increased resilience to â€¢ Improved transport (primary, secondary, natural disasters connectivity tertiary) (urban/coastal) â€¢ Improved delivery of â€¢ Improved access to â€¢ Improved water resource basic services by local quality health services management for climate government â€¢ Improved social resilience â€¢ Enhanced business protection coverage for â€¢ Increased adoption of environment for regional the poor sustainable agriculture & global integration â€¢ Enhanced income practice â€¢ Increased financial opportunities for the intermediation poor
Governance & Institutional Strengthening Foundation â€¢ Revenue mobilization and public financial management, at central and local levels â€¢ Public sector reform, including procurement, auditing and oversight  Country Partnership Framework (3)
World Bank Group in Bangladesh
IDA has a portfolio of $8.3 billion and includes 36 projects â€¢ About 40 percent of current program involves infrastructure â€¢ In FY15, the World Bank board approved $1.92 billion new IDA financing. â€¢ Since independence, IDA has committed nearly $20 billion in interest-free credits (40 year maturity, 10 year grace period) â€¢ In FY15, IDA disbursements reached $882million.
IFC has a committed portfolio of $802 million
â€¢ Portfolio has grown expanded from $100M to over $800M over the past 5 years; number of projects grew to over 40. â€¢ Bangladesh is one of IFCâ€™s top 20 portfolios (by vol). â€¢ In FY15, investment commitments totaled $650 million â€¢ Bangladesh has IFCâ€™s largest country-specific advisory programs, with focus on investment climate, RMG sector safety and sustainability, inclusion and agriculture.
MIGA has $251 million of exposure  Country Partnership Framework (4)

Key Areas of IFC Focus: Enhancing Competitiveness
Addressing Critical Infrastructure Manufacturing Diversification/ Financial Inclusion Gaps Strengthening â€¢ Power â€“generation and â€¢ Diversify sources of finance â€¢ Diversification into white goods, transmission â€¢ Access to financial services for ceramics, pharmaceuticals, and â€¢ Fuel Supplyâ€”natural gas and the underserved, including high value food processing LNG MSMEs and women â€¢ Enhancing environmental and â€¢ Inland waterways, Ports, â€¢ Capital markets development, social sustainability of the RMG Logistics Hubs e.g., Taka bond issue sector â€¢ Special Economic Zones â€¢ Strengthening the commercial â€¢ Urban Infrastructure banking sector â€¢ Telecom/ICT â€¢ LT and STF finance for trade and priority sectors
Enhancing Business Enabling Climate Smart Solutions Social Inclusion Environment â€¢ Support PPP approaches â€¢ Water and energy efficiency â€¢ Agribusinessâ€”diversification â€¢ Modernize and reform legal enhancements to higher value crops and regulatory framework that â€¢ Promote adoption of sustainable â€¢ Critical commodities financing governs private sector climate smart agribusiness technologies and practices. â€¢ Access to quality health care â€¢ Remove bottlenecks in Infra facilities â€¢ Renewable energy and energy Policy â€¢ Organized retail outlets for efficiency projects â€¢ Environmentally sustainable agri/food products investments  Country Partnership Framework (6)

doc.repnme: Bangladesh - Creating more and better jobs for poverty reduction
doc.abstracts: Bangladesh performed better than expected since independence in 1971. It will partially achieve MDGs for poverty reduction and primary enrolment, and is on track for gender parity in education, child mortality, maternal health, HIV/AIDs and tuberculosis. This resulted from attention to health outcomes, primary education, family planning, and gender equality (especially in education and workforce participation), supported by female grass-roots workers and organizers mobilized by the GoBand world-leading NGOs.
